Frank Harris Letters to Constance Ruth Bonsall
Harris, Frank, 1855-1931
Kinloch, Robert
MSS.561
.25 Linear Feet in one half letter manuscript box.
1916, Undated This collection consists of personal letters from Irish author and editor Frank Harris to Constance Ruth Bonsall in 1916, at the time an aspiring young English writer. Materials are in English. Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
Scope and Contents
This collection consists of personal letters from Irish author and editor Frank Harris to Constance Ruth Bonsall in 1916, at the time an aspiring young English writer.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Robert Kinloch in November 2018. The accession number associated with this donation is 2018.126.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Conditions Governing Use
This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).
Arrangement
This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.
Processing Information
Materials were removed from plastic sleeves and placed into an acid-free folder and box.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Frank Harris Letters to Constance Ruth Bonsall; MSS 561; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University.
Biographical Note
Frank Harris (born James Thomas Harris, 1856â€“1931) was an Irish editor, author, and journalist famous for his sexually explicit memoir My Life and Loves, as well as for his friendships with notable public and literary figures including Oscar Wilde, George Bernard Shaw, and Aleister Crowley. Harris was editor of London publications theEvening News, theFortnightly Review,The Saturday Review (for which he hired George Bernard Shaw), and the U.S. edition ofPearson's Magazine. In addition toMy Life and Loves, his work includesOscar Wilde: His Life and Confessions, Life of Bernard Shaw, andContemporary Portraits.
Constance Ruth Bonsall (1898-1994) was an aspiring English writer and the youngest daughter of a Devonshire vicar. She wrote in the 1920s using the pseudonym Charlotte Apple, and later published three novels under her maiden name (Ruth Bonsall) and her married name (Ruth Kinloch).
